node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Briefing The war on terror improved neither America's standing nor the nation itself'.

node.text:
The horror of that day—September 11th 2001—unified America. It also seemed to offer the prospect of global solidarity. ⁠
⁠
“The world has changed in a way that we are all vulnerable,” said Joe Biden, the chairman of the Senate foreign-relations committee, the following day.⁠
⁠
A few weeks later, he imagined how that new purpose “could shape this half-century as the cold war shaped the last”. A big claim. ⁠
⁠
Twenty years on, the world is not the one Joe Biden hoped for, in which America and China shared interests in fighting terrorism. ⁠
⁠
America’s post-9/11 mission in the world has failed to strengthen an international order that conforms to America’s values.⁠
⁠
The way in which Mr Biden has ended the wars of 9/11 by withdrawing from Afghanistan does mark the end, for now, of a faded idea, about the imperative of spreading America’s ideals throughout the world.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read our briefing this week, which argues that America wasted the influence it had after the events of two decades ago. ⁠
⁠
Credit: @elliefp

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Texas. May be an illustration.

node.text:
⁠Anyone based anywhere in America can now sue a Texan who assists in the provision of an abortion after about six weeks, from the taxi driver who drove a woman to a clinic to the nurses working there. ⁠
⁠
As an encouragement to do so, successful plaintiffs will have their legal costs paid and receive a $10,000 reward. ⁠
⁠
Many expected the Supreme Court to put the law on hold because it contradicted a right to abortion. But through their inaction, the justices in the majority have permitted America’s legal system to be hacked. ⁠
⁠
The Biden administration has now sued Texas over the state’s law. The Justice Department contends that Roe v Wade, a Supreme Court precedent permitting abortion before roughly 24 weeks, renders Texas’s law unconstitutional. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why Texas's bounty-hunting abortion law is not just bad news for Texan women, it is also bad for the rule of law.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @kaltoons1

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Kabul, Afghanistan. May be an image of one or more people, outdoors and text that says 'The Economist explains The Taliban plan to rule Afghanistan in accordance with sharia law. What is it?'.

node.text:
Sharia law is based on the Koran, Islam’s holy book; the hadith, or sayings of the prophet Mohammed; and the subsequent work of Islamic legal scholars.⁠
⁠
Although parts of sharia law are set out in the Koran, most of the system, like other legal frameworks, is flexible. It covers criminal, commercial and family law but is much more holistic than secular legal systems: it also sets out the ethical rules that Muslims should aim to live and worship by.⁠
⁠
Afghanistan’s new Taliban government has promised moderation. Whether or not it means it will come down to its interpretation of sharia. Tap the link in our bio to read our explainer.⁠
⁠
Credit: Aamir Qureshi/AFP via Getty Images

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 09, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Science & technology A new AIDS vaccine heads to clinical trials 立士立立一'.

node.text:
⁠Three decades of attempts to create a vaccine against HIV have been fruitless. The virus has a high mutation rate, which helps it adapt to evade both natural immune systems and artificial vaccines. ⁠
⁠
But there may be a new hope.⁠
⁠
Moderna, an American firm that found fame by quickly coming up with a viable covid-19 jab, is planning human trials of a novel vaccine against HIV. ⁠
⁠
Its researchers hope the same mRNA technology will succeed against HIV too, by creating a vaccine which the virus cannot easily dodge.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to discover how Moderna's AIDS vaccine works. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @nadihaf

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in San Salvador. May be an image of 1 person, beard, standing and text that says 'POLO'.

node.text:
Nayib Bukele is wrecking democracy in El Salvador.⁠
⁠
He is seen as an answer to gang violence and corruption. But look beyond his nerdy puffery, and there lies an old-fashioned autocrat.⁠
⁠
His law making bitcoin legal tender, along with the US dollar, is domineering. It will force businesses to accept the cryptocurrency, though few want to do so.⁠
⁠
And while he has become an unlikely hero to some tech bros in Silicon Valley, voters should be wary.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how this wildly popular leader, with approval ratings hovering at around 90%, used gun-toting soldiers to bully opposition lawmakers and disbanded an anti-corruption body.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Jose Cabeza

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'The Economist explains How bad are e-cigarettes for you? Regulators are trying to decide'.

node.text:
America’s Food and Drug Administration rushed to meet a September 9th deadline to decide whether more than 6.5m e-cigarette products made by over 500 companies can remain on the market. 

When the deadline arrived, the agency had made determinations covering about 93% of the products submitted for review. It will block the sale of more than 946,000 flavoured products. But on the question of Juul—the largest player, with 40% of the market for e-cigarettes—regulators said they need more time. 

E-cigarettes have attracted keen government attention in recent years.

Regulators and politicians are right to worry about the long-term effects of e-cigarettes, but widespread bans risk keeping smokers on conventional cigarettes. E-cigarettes are bad for health and their flavoured options make them more attractive to younger consumers. But they are far less harmful to one’s health than a traditional smoke.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the policies regarding nicotine products in America are changing.

Editor’s note: We’ve updated this post to reflect the latest news from the FDA. 
⁠
Credit: Mike Kemp/In PIctures via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Mexico City, Mexico. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and text that says 'The Americas Mexico's a Supreme Court decriminalises abortion'.

node.text:
Mexico’s Supreme Court unanimously voted to decriminalise abortion. ⁠
⁠
The loosening of abortion restrictions is the culmination of a small but growing wave of piecemeal liberalisation in the country.⁠
⁠
Abortions will not immediately become available, but judges in all states can no longer prosecute women for having an abortion, and must release any women or doctors behind bars for terminating pregnancies.⁠
⁠
Decriminalising abortion in Mexico is significant—not least because it happened days after Texas introduced a law banning abortion after six weeks. Tap the link in our bio to read why the ruling reflects changing mores in the world’s second-biggest Catholic country.⁠
⁠
Credit: Antonio Ojeda/Agencia Press South/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The Economist America twenty years on SEPTEMBER 9/11 Why nations that fail women fail'.

node.text:
The gains that Afghan women and girls have made in the past 20 years are now in jeopardy.⁠
⁠
After America and its allies toppled the Taliban in 2001, primary-school enrolment of Afghan girls rose from 0% to above 80%. Infant mortality fell by half. Forced marriage was made illegal.⁠
⁠
America is "committed to advancing gender equality" through its foreign policy, says the State Department. Bequeathing billions of dollars-worth of arms and a medium-sized country to a group of violent misogynists is an odd way to show it.⁠
⁠
Societies that oppress women are far more likely to be violent and unstable. To read why policymakers who fail to consider the interests of half the population cannot hope to understand the world, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Cover illustration: @andrea_ucini

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Leaders Boris Johnson deserves credit for reforming Britain's social care'.

node.text:
Boris Johnson unveiled a plan to break an election promise and raise taxes by 0.5% of GDP. The money will go to Britain’s National Health Service and social care, including residential care for the elderly. ⁠
⁠
The reform was necessary, but the way it is being paid for is far from ideal.⁠
⁠
Outrageously, income from pensions and property will escape higher levies, meaning many well-off elderly voters will be spared from paying anything for a reform that largely benefits them. ⁠
⁠
Had the government raised income tax instead, every generation would have contributed.⁠
⁠
Mr Johnson’s self-reinvention as a politician willing to take an unpopular but necessary decision is welcome. ⁠
⁠
Many more such decisions will be needed, preferably with better funding mechanisms. Tap on the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Glyn Kirk/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of text that says 'Finance & economics Could climate change trigger a financial crisis? A lot hangs on governments'.

node.text:
Just how financially damaging does climate risk stand to be?⁠
⁠
Early stress tests by central banks and disclosures of companies are starting to shed light on the question, and suggest that the impact on large banks and insurers may be manageable. ⁠
⁠
But a lot hangs on whether governments set out a clear path for reducing emissions, such as through carbon taxes and energy-efficiency standards, giving banks enough time to prepare. ⁠
⁠
To read how climate change can affect the financial system, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Asia The Delta variant has brought devastation to South-East Asia'.

node.text:
All through 2020 and the early part of this year, it looked like South-East Asia had escaped the worst of the pandemic. ⁠
⁠
But no longer. By the end of August, South-East Asia had recorded some 217,000 deaths from covid, about 2.6 times its total just three months earlier. ⁠
⁠
When the highly infectious Delta variant arrived in the region this year, it encountered a population that lacked any immunity, was complacent after a covid-free year and was defended by public-health measures designed for the milder, original form of the virus. ⁠
⁠
The worst may be over for South-East Asia, at least for now. New infections are declining sharply in Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why the disease's effects will long be felt in hunger, unemployment and lost opportunities in the region. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Aditya Aji/ Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of skyscraper.

node.text:
In some ways America is worse off now than it was on September 10th 2001: more anxious, more polarised, less trusting. New York City, though, is better.⁠
⁠
For New Yorkers staggered by the shock of 9/11, rebuilding became a rallying cause, a way of not letting the terrorists win.⁠
⁠
The residential population of Lower Manhattan more than doubled between 2001 and 2020, as did the number of residential units. New York’s population, infrastructure, and business boomed in their post-tragedy revival. ⁠
⁠
Tap on the link in our bio to read more about how New York built back better after the worst day in the city’s history.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ashley Gilbertson/New York Times/Redux/eyevine
